evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS Mobile is mature software that has been under development since 2012
evidence.verbatim_quote: It is mature software that has been under development since 2012

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS Mobile current code version is 2.5, software version 2.5.20
evidence.verbatim_quote: Current code version 2.5

evidence.evidence_text: Software is licensed under GPLv3
evidence.verbatim_quote: Legal Code License GPLv3

evidence.evidence_text: Code repository is hosted on GitHub at ElsevierSoftwareX repository
evidence.verbatim_quote: Permanent link to repository used for this code version https://github.com/ElsevierSoftwareX/SOFTX-D-17-00021

evidence.evidence_text: Software uses Java, Ruby, XML, SQLite, Spatialite, Javarosa, Antlr, Puppet, Apache, Imagemagick, God, Beanshell, gson, guice, Nutiteq, NativeCSS, Protobuf, Robotium
evidence.verbatim_quote: Software code languages, tools, and services used Java, Ruby, XML, SQLite, Spatialite, Javarosa, Antlr, Puppet, Apache, Imagemagick, God, Beanshell, gson, guice, Nutiteq (non-free), NativeCSS, Protobuf, Robotium

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS Mobile requires Android 6+ and Ubuntu 16.04 for server
evidence.verbatim_quote: Installation requirements & dependencies Android 6+, Ubuntu 16.04

evidence.evidence_text: Three deployment case studies were published in Sobotkova et al., 2016
evidence.verbatim_quote: Three deployment case studies have been published in Sobotkova et al., 2016

evidence.evidence_text: Projects have independently customised FAIMS Mobile using both detailed definition packet approach and simplified DSL-based method
evidence.verbatim_quote: In addition to deployments conducted by the FAIMS team, projects have independently customised FAIMS Mobile themselves using both the detailed approach of producing an entire definition packet and the simplified DSL-based method

evidence.evidence_text: Five years of deployment experience revealed importance of quality assurance in academic software
evidence.verbatim_quote: Five years of deployment experience revealed the importance of quality assurance, something too often neglected in academic software

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS Mobile 2.5+ supports Robotium for unit and integration tests
evidence.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile 2.5+ supports Robotium for unit and integration tests on customised data collection modules, such that large amounts of test data can be automatically added via the normal user interface

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS uses Javarosa to render native Android UI elements at runtime
evidence.verbatim_quote: Javarosa to render native Android UI elements at runtime

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS uses Sqlite3 for attribute-key-value datastore with runtime-definable data schemas
evidence.verbatim_quote: Sqlite3 to store an attribute-key-value datastore (with data schemas definable at runtime)

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS uses an append-only data model inspired by Google's Protobufs
evidence.verbatim_quote: An append-only data model inspired by Google's Protobufs

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS uses Spatialite to encode geospatial data and Nutiteq to render it
evidence.verbatim_quote: Spatialite to encode geospatial data in the datastore; Nutiteq to render geospatial data

evidence.evidence_text: Server uses Ruby on Rails/Apache stack that can be hosted online or on modest hardware in the field
evidence.verbatim_quote: A Ruby on Rails/Apache stack to provide a server for synchronisation, version review, user management, and similar tasks, which can be hosted online or on modest hardware in the field

evidence.evidence_text: Since 2014 public release, FAIMS Mobile has been customised at least 40 times with 29 confirmed field deployments, nine including multiple field seasons
evidence.verbatim_quote: Since our first public release in 2014, FAIMS Mobile has been customised at least 40 times (by our team or independently), with 29 confirmed field deployments, nine of which included multiple field seasons

evidence.evidence_text: Approximately 300 users have logged over 20,000 hours using FAIMS for archaeology, ecology, geoscience, and history research
evidence.verbatim_quote: Considering only FAIMS-led development, approximately 300 users have logged over 20,000 h employing the software for archaeology, ecology, geoscience, and history research

evidence.evidence_text: An experienced developer can rapidly prototype a recording system in one to two developer-days for well-scoped systems of moderate complexity
evidence.verbatim_quote: An experienced developer can rapidly prototype a recording system if data and workflow models are available (well-scoped systems of moderate complexity can be prototyped in one to two developer-days)

evidence.evidence_text: Case studies showed users benefited from increased efficiency of fieldwork with time saved by avoiding digitisation and data cleaning more than offsetting implementation time
evidence.verbatim_quote: Three case studies involving archaeological deployments showed that users benefited from the increased efficiency of fieldwork. The time saved by avoiding digitisation and data cleaning more than offset the time required to implement FAIMS, resulting in more data collected during fieldwork of a given duration

evidence.evidence_text: Researchers reported more complete, consistent, and granular data
evidence.verbatim_quote: Researchers reported more complete, consistent, and granular data

evidence.evidence_text: Information exchange between excavators and specialists was faster, improving post-excavation reconstruction in one case and facilitating pattern evaluation in another
evidence.verbatim_quote: They noted that information could be exchanged more quickly between excavators and specialists, which in one case improved 'post-excavation reconstruction of the site' and facilitated the evaluation of patterns for meaning in another

evidence.evidence_text: Process of moving from paper to digital required comprehensive reviews of field practice making implicit knowledge explicit
evidence.verbatim_quote: They also observed that the process of moving from paper to digital required comprehensive reviews of field practice, during which knowledge implicit in existing systems became explicit, and data was modelled more carefully

evidence.evidence_text: Greatest challenge was reallocation of time from end of project (digitisation) to beginning (data modelling, development, testing)
evidence.verbatim_quote: The greatest challenge posed by the transition from paper has been the reallocation of time from the end of a project (digitisation) to the beginning (data modelling, development, and testing), even if an overall time-savings is realised

evidence.evidence_text: A 2016-2018 NSW Research Attraction and Acceleration Program award is funding deployments at additional projects including community heritage and citizen science applications
evidence.verbatim_quote: A 2016â€“2018 New South Wales Research Attraction and Acceleration Program award is funding deployments at additional projects, including community heritage and citizen science applications, where members of the public can download preconfigured versions of FAIMS Mobile from Google Play

evidence.evidence_text: Multiple funding sources supported the work including NeCTAR, ARC, NSW Government, and multiple universities
evidence.verbatim_quote: This work was supported by the National eResearch Collaboration Tools and Resources programme (RT043; V005), the Australian Research Council (LE140100151), the New South Wales Government Research Attraction and Acceleration Program, Macquarie University, Flinders University, La Trobe University, Southern Cross University, the University of Queensland, the University of Sydney, UNSW Australia, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation ON Prime programme, and fees paid by our users for consultation, customisation, deployment, and support services

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS uses Beanshell to provide runtime scripting via calls to underlying Java API
evidence.verbatim_quote: Beanshell to provide runtime scripting via calls to an underlying Java API

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS uses NativeCSS to style android-native elements
evidence.verbatim_quote: NativeCSS to style android-native elements

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS uses Antlr3 as a grammar parser for identifiers
evidence.verbatim_quote: Antlr3 as a grammar parser for identifiers

evidence.evidence_text: User to Developer documentation and FAIMS Cookbook are available for module creation
evidence.verbatim_quote: 'FAIMS User to Developer Documentation' is designed to walk users through the creation of a module from first principles. The 'FAIMS Cookbook' is a tutorial covering data structures and API

evidence.evidence_text: Definition packets consist of XML documents for data schema and UI, plus Beanshell scripts for automation
evidence.verbatim_quote: which can be deeply customised using 'definition packets' consisting of XML documents (data schema and UI) and Beanshell scripts (automation)

evidence.evidence_text: Definition packets can be generated using XML-based domain-specific language for easier customisation
evidence.verbatim_quote: Definition packets can also be generated using an XML-based domain-specific language, making customisation easier

evidence.evidence_text: Multiple modules available in GitHub library for reuse or modification
evidence.verbatim_quote: Users who are satisfied with one of the many modules in our GitHub library can also simply instantiate an existing customisation

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS originated in archaeology where investigator records observations about things in material world and relationships between those observations
evidence.verbatim_quote: FAIMS originated in archaeology, where an investigator records observations about things in the material world, relationships between those observations, and metadata contextualising the collection of those observations

evidence.evidence_text: ODK was designed for social surveys where investigator asks questions of an interviewee
evidence.verbatim_quote: ODK was designed for social surveys, where an investigator asks questions of a interviewee

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS has features not in ODK: nuanced relationships between entities, bi-directional synchronisation, append-only datastore with version history, wider sensor/peripheral support, more sophisticated export, and advanced geospatial operations
evidence.verbatim_quote: It also includes features not found in ODK: more nuanced relationships between entities, bi-directional synchronisation across all devices (a feature in ODK 2.0 Tool Suite, which is in alpha release), use of an append-only datastore that provides a version history for all records, support for a wider range of external sensors and peripherals like label printers ('ODK Sensors' is in alpha release), a more sophisticated data export framework, and more advanced geospatial data operations

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS has richer and more granular help and metadata capture than ODK
evidence.verbatim_quote: FAIMS also has richer and more granular help and metadata capture

evidence.evidence_text: Support email available at support@fedarch.org
evidence.verbatim_quote: Support email for questions support@fedarch.org

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS Mobile executables available from fedarch.org and Google Play
evidence.verbatim_quote: Permanent link to executables of this version FAIMS Mobile https://www.fedarch.org/apk Google Play https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=au.edu.faims.mq.fieldresearch2&hl=en

evidence.evidence_text: Server installer available via wget and pipe to bash from GitHub
evidence.verbatim_quote: Server Installer (wget and pipe to bash) https://raw.githubusercontent.com/FAIMS/faims-web/master/installer/puppetInstall.sh

evidence.evidence_text: User documentation available at Atlassian wiki for Getting Started guide
evidence.verbatim_quote: Link to user manual 'Getting started' guide and user documentation: https://faimsproject.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/MobileUser/overview

evidence.evidence_text: Developer documentation available including Module Cookbook and Beanshell API
evidence.verbatim_quote: Link to developer documentation/manual Module Cookbook https://faimsproject.atlassian.net/wiki/x/RgAu Module Beanshell API https://faimsproject.atlassian.net/wiki/x/RwAu Developer documentation home https://faimsproject.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/FAIMS/overview

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS Project provides customisation services under typical open-source revenue model
evidence.verbatim_quote: The FAIMS Project provides customisation services under a typical open-source revenue model

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS Project is based at Macquarie University, Sydney, Australia
evidence.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile is open-source software developed by the Field Acquired Information Management Systems Project, an e-research infrastructure project based at Macquarie University, Sydney, Australia

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile is mature software suitable for field research
claims.verbatim_quote: It is mature software that has been under development since 2012

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile has undergone iterative co-development with field researchers for five years
claims.verbatim_quote: It is purpose-built for field research with extensive community input, including five years of iterative co-development with field researchers first in archaeology, and more recently in geoscience, history, and ecology

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile is free and open-source software
claims.verbatim_quote: The software is free (as in speech), customisable, and extensible, accommodating arbitrary research designs

claims.claim_text: Open-source licensing allows researchers to build and share customisations
claims.verbatim_quote: Researchers can also build and share their own customisations

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile uses robust technology stack of Java and Ruby with multiple supporting libraries
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile consists of 'core' software written in Java and Ruby, customised to particular field deployments using reusable definition packets consisting of XML, Beanshell, and CSS files

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile operates on standard Android devices and Ubuntu servers
claims.verbatim_quote: Computing platforms/Operating Systems Android, Ubuntu

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile has been validated through published deployment case studies
claims.verbatim_quote: Three deployment case studies have been published in Sobotkova et al., 2016

claims.claim_text: Deployment case studies provide evidence of software effectiveness
claims.verbatim_quote: Three deployment case studies have been published in Sobotkova et al., 2016

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile can be customised independently by users without FAIMS team involvement
claims.verbatim_quote: In addition to deployments conducted by the FAIMS team, projects have independently customised FAIMS Mobile themselves using both the detailed approach of producing an entire definition packet and the simplified DSL-based method

claims.claim_text: Independent customisation demonstrates software accessibility to broader user community
claims.verbatim_quote: In addition to deployments conducted by the FAIMS team, projects have independently customised FAIMS Mobile themselves

claims.claim_text: Quality assurance is critically important for academic software deployments
claims.verbatim_quote: Five years of deployment experience revealed the importance of quality assurance, something too often neglected in academic software

claims.claim_text: Each customisation and deployment is a miniature software development project
claims.verbatim_quote: Each customisation and deployment is, indeed, a miniature software development project

claims.claim_text: Robotium support allows load-testing modules under simulated field conditions
claims.verbatim_quote: This allows users to load-test their modules under simulated field conditions

claims.claim_text: FAIMS architecture separates core client from definition packets similar to browser-website distinction
claims.verbatim_quote: This distinction between the 'core' client and the definition packet resembles the one between a web browser and a website

claims.claim_text: Runtime-definable data schemas accommodate wide range of research designs
claims.verbatim_quote: Sqlite3 to store an attribute-key-value datastore (with data schemas definable at runtime)

claims.claim_text: Append-only datastore provides complete version history for all records
claims.verbatim_quote: An append-only datastore providing a full revision history, including the ability to review and reverse changes to records selectively

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile includes mobile GIS capabilities for geospatial data
claims.verbatim_quote: Mobile GIS supporting raster and vector data, layer management, legacy data visualisation, and point, line, and polygon creation and editing

claims.claim_text: Server can be deployed on modest hardware in field locations
claims.verbatim_quote: which can be hosted online or on modest hardware in the field

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile software is publicly accessible through multiple distribution channels
claims.verbatim_quote: Permanent link to repository used for this code version https://github.com/ElsevierSoftwareX/SOFTX-D-17-00021

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile has achieved significant uptake in field research community
claims.verbatim_quote: Although the transition to digital recording during fieldwork represents a significant socio-technical change, FAIMS Mobile has seen good uptake

claims.claim_text: Multiple field seasons by nine projects demonstrates sustained real-world use
claims.verbatim_quote: with 29 confirmed field deployments, nine of which included multiple field seasons

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile is used across multiple disciplines beyond archaeology
claims.verbatim_quote: employing the software for archaeology, ecology, geoscience, and history research

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile enables rapid prototyping of data collection systems
claims.verbatim_quote: An experienced developer can rapidly prototype a recording system if data and workflow models are available

claims.claim_text: One to two developer-days is sufficient for moderate complexity customisations
claims.verbatim_quote: well-scoped systems of moderate complexity can be prototyped in one to two developer-days

claims.claim_text: Digital data collection using FAIMS increases fieldwork efficiency
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS allows the efficient collection of field data, dramatically reducing or eliminating manual digitisation

claims.claim_text: Time savings from avoiding digitisation offset implementation time investment
claims.verbatim_quote: The time saved by avoiding digitisation and data cleaning more than offset the time required to implement FAIMS, resulting in more data collected during fieldwork of a given duration

claims.claim_text: FAIMS improves data quality through more complete, consistent and granular recording
claims.verbatim_quote: Researchers reported more complete, consistent, and granular data

claims.claim_text: Near-real-time data availability improves collaboration and analysis during fieldwork
claims.verbatim_quote: They noted that information could be exchanged more quickly between excavators and specialists

claims.claim_text: Transition to digital recording makes implicit field knowledge explicit through data modelling process
claims.verbatim_quote: knowledge implicit in existing systems became explicit, and data was modelled more carefully

claims.claim_text: Transition from paper requires reallocation of effort from end to beginning of projects
claims.verbatim_quote: The greatest challenge posed by the transition from paper has been the reallocation of time from the end of a project (digitisation) to the beginning (data modelling, development, and testing)

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile is expanding into community heritage and citizen science applications
claims.verbatim_quote: funding deployments at additional projects, including community heritage and citizen science applications

claims.claim_text: FAIMS development has been supported by diverse funding sources demonstrating institutional recognition
claims.verbatim_quote: This work was supported by the National eResearch Collaboration Tools and Resources programme (RT043; V005), the Australian Research Council (LE140100151), the New South Wales Government Research Attraction and Acceleration Program

claims.claim_text: Comprehensive documentation supports both users and developers
claims.verbatim_quote: 'FAIMS User to Developer Documentation' is designed to walk users through the creation of a module from first principles

claims.claim_text: FAIMS architecture enables deep customisation without modifying core software
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS, conversely, supports more profound customisation without modification of core software

claims.claim_text: Domain-specific language simplifies customisation at expense of some independent control
claims.verbatim_quote: Using this DSL, a single file is used to generate a complete definition packet, at the expense of some loss of independent control over each element of a customisation

claims.claim_text: Existing module library on GitHub reduces deployment costs through reuse
claims.verbatim_quote: Reuse and modification of existing customisations from a growing, openly-licensed online library (available on GitHub) also helps to reduce deployment costs

claims.claim_text: FAIMS design reflects archaeology's need to record complex relationships between observations
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS originated in archaeology, where an investigator records observations about things in the material world, relationships between those observations, and metadata contextualising the collection of those observations

claims.claim_text: ODK's survey-focused design differs from FAIMS's observation-focused design
claims.verbatim_quote: ODK was designed for social surveys, where an investigator asks questions of a interviewee. FAIMS originated in archaeology, where an investigator records observations about things in the material world

claims.claim_text: FAIMS is differentiated from ODK by its lineage and features
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile is most comparable to Open Data Kit (ODK) and its variants, but is differentiated by its lineage

claims.claim_text: FAIMS is more customisable with more fieldwork-specific features than ODK but customisation is more entailed
claims.verbatim_quote: In short, FAIMS is more customisable and has more fieldwork-specific features than ODK, but as a result customisation is more entailed

claims.claim_text: Support infrastructure exists for user questions
claims.verbatim_quote: Support email for questions support@fedarch.org

claims.claim_text: Software distribution through multiple channels increases accessibility
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile https://www.fedarch.org/apk Google Play https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=au.edu.faims.mq.fieldresearch2&hl=en

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Project offers professional customisation services
claims.verbatim_quote: The FAIMS Project provides customisation services under a typical open-source revenue model

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Project is an e-research infrastructure project at Macquarie University
claims.verbatim_quote: an e-research infrastructure project based at Macquarie University, Sydney, Australia

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile represents a viable solution for field research data collection challenges
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile offers an alternative. It is purpose-built for field research with extensive community input

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile is designed for rapid prototyping and easy redeployability to reduce implementation costs
claims.verbatim_quote: Finally, it is designed for rapid prototyping using and easy redeployability to reduce the costs of implementation

claims.claim_text: Transition from paper to digital recording represents significant socio-technical change
claims.verbatim_quote: Although the transition to digital recording during fieldwork represents a significant socio-technical change

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile offers unparalleled range of features to support fieldwork
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile offers an unparallelled range of features to support fieldwork

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile supports offline capability with opportunistic synchronisation
claims.verbatim_quote: offline capability with opportunistic synchronisation using either an online or local server

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile is generalised software that can support transition from paper to digital across field disciplines
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile is community-driven, customisable, extensible software that can support the socio-technical transition from paper to digital in field research disciplines

claims.claim_text: Field research disciplines often lack transparency and reproducibility
claims.verbatim_quote: Field research disciplines, however, often lack transparency and reproducibility, compromising the integrity of research results

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile promotes synthetic research and improves transparency and reproducibility
claims.verbatim_quote: It also promotes synthetic research and improves transparency and reproducibility through the production of comprehensive datasets that can be mapped to vocabularies or ontologies as they are created

claims.claim_text: Field data is often collected using ad-hoc mix of hard copy, data fragments and bespoke databases
claims.verbatim_quote: Field data is often collected using an ad-hoc mix of hard copy, data fragments in various formats, and bespoke databases

claims.claim_text: Digital datasets are often highly variable, of poor quality, and incompatible
claims.verbatim_quote: Digital datasets are often highly variable, of poor quality, and incompatible

claims.claim_text: Bespoke software is expensive placing it beyond reach of all but best-funded projects
claims.verbatim_quote: Bespoke software is expensive to build and maintain, placing it beyond the reach of all but the best-funded projects and organisations

claims.claim_text: FAIMS customisation is less expensive than bespoke mobile application production
claims.verbatim_quote: Customisation of FAIMS Mobile is therefore less expensive than production of bespoke mobile applications

claims.claim_text: FAIMS supports embedding URIs in controlled vocabularies connecting to linked open data sources
claims.verbatim_quote: URIs can be embedded in controlled vocabularies and other elements, connecting them to linked open data sources

claims.claim_text: Comprehensive datasets can be created and exported for publication improving transparency and reproducibility
claims.verbatim_quote: Perhaps most importantly, comprehensive, rather than selective, datasets can be created and exported for publication, improving transparency and reproducibility

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Field researchers have sufficient technical capability to adopt digital data collection tools
trigger_text: projects have independently customised FAIMS Mobile themselves
An experienced developer can rapidly prototype a recording system
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Paper assumes field research teams either have or can access technical expertise for customisation. Independent customisation and 'experienced developer' references imply assumption that technical capacity exists in or is available to research teams.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Android devices are suitable and available platforms for field research data collection
trigger_text: native Android application
Android 6+
as many Android devices as needed
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Paper assumes Android platform is appropriate for field research without justifying platform choice. This assumes Android devices are sufficiently robust, affordable, and available for field conditions across diverse research contexts.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Digital data collection provides advantages that justify transition costs from paper-based systems
trigger_text: The time saved by avoiding digitisation and data cleaning more than offset the time required to implement FAIMS
The greatest challenge posed by the transition from paper has been the reallocation of time
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Paper acknowledges transition challenges but assumes benefits outweigh costs. This bridges from evidence of time reallocation to conclusion that digital is preferable, without explicit cost-benefit analysis for all project types.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Case studies from archaeology are generalisable to other field research disciplines
trigger_text: Three deployment case studies have been published in Sobotkova et al., 2016
employing the software for archaeology, ecology, geoscience, and history research
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The detailed case studies cited are from archaeology, yet claims are made about suitability for ecology, geoscience, and history. This assumes archaeological deployment experiences transfer to other disciplinary contexts.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: User-reported outcomes accurately reflect software effectiveness
trigger_text: Researchers reported more complete, consistent, and granular data
users benefited from the increased efficiency of fieldwork
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Evidence for software effectiveness relies primarily on user self-reports. Paper assumes these subjective assessments accurately capture objective improvements in data quality and efficiency.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Five years of development constitutes sufficient maturity for field research software
trigger_text: It is mature software that has been under development since 2012
Five years of deployment experience
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Paper equates development duration with maturity. This assumes time-based development correlates with software quality and field-readiness, without defining maturity criteria.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Open-source development model is sustainable for specialised research software
trigger_text: The FAIMS Project provides customisation services under a typical open-source revenue model
fees paid by our users for consultation, customisation, deployment, and support services
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Paper presents open-source model as viable without demonstrating long-term sustainability. Funding sources listed include grants and user fees, implying assumption that this mixed model can sustain development.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Comparison with ODK is the most relevant benchmark for FAIMS evaluation
trigger_text: FAIMS Mobile is most comparable to Open Data Kit (ODK) and its variants
Field research projects, especially in liminal disciplines such as linguistics or oral history, would be wise to evaluate both platforms
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Paper positions ODK as primary comparison point, assuming this is the most relevant benchmark. Other potential comparators (e.g., proprietary solutions, discipline-specific tools) receive less attention.

research_designs.design_text: Software publication describing field data collection platform with feature documentation and impact assessment
Comparative positioning against existing tools (particularly ODK) to demonstrate unique value proposition
trigger_text: FAIMS Mobile is most comparable to Open Data Kit (ODK)
FAIMS is more customisable and has more fieldwork-specific features than ODK
research_designs.inference_reasoning: Paper systematically compares FAIMS to ODK throughout, positioning FAIMS relative to the market. This comparative framing is not stated as explicit design choice but structures the argument.

research_designs.design_text: Evidence-based impact assessment using deployment metrics and user feedback
trigger_text: Since our first public release in 2014, FAIMS Mobile has been customised at least 40 times
Three case studies involving archaeological deployments showed that users benefited
research_designs.inference_reasoning: Impact section presents quantitative metrics and qualitative user feedback as evidence of software value. This systematic evidence gathering approach is not explicitly framed as a research design.

research_designs.design_text: Architecture documentation demonstrating technical design decisions and rationale
research_designs.verbatim_quote: We developed this architecture to meet two fundamental requirements: (1) the software had to accommodate a wide range of research designs, data schemas, and workflows, and (2) the software had to accommodate extremely variable structured, free text, multimedia, and geospatial data

methods.method_text: Technical documentation of software architecture including component descriptions and technology stack
methods.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile consists of 'core' software written in Java and Ruby, customised to particular field deployments using reusable definition packets consisting of XML, Beanshell, and CSS files

methods.method_text: Impact assessment through compilation of deployment metrics, user counts, and qualitative feedback from case studies
trigger_text: FAIMS Mobile has been customised at least 40 times
approximately 300 users have logged over 20,000 h
Three case studies involving archaeological deployments showed
methods.inference_reasoning: Paper presents deployment statistics and case study findings but does not explicitly describe how this data was collected or compiled. The method of gathering impact evidence is implied rather than documented.

methods.method_text: Feature comparison with alternative platforms particularly ODK
trigger_text: FAIMS Mobile is most comparable to Open Data Kit (ODK)
It also includes features not found in ODK
methods.inference_reasoning: Paper compares FAIMS features to ODK but doesn't describe comparison methodology. Selection of comparison points and evaluation criteria are not explicitly documented.

methods.method_text: Software functionality documentation with illustrative examples
methods.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile improves field research by providing a wide range of features that specifically address the needs of field research across disciplines

protocols.protocol_text: Component-by-component description of technology stack (Javarosa, Sqlite3, Protobuf-inspired model, Beanshell, Spatialite, Nutiteq, NativeCSS, Antlr3, Ruby on Rails/Apache)
protocols.verbatim_quote: More specifically, FAIMS uses the following technologies: Javarosa to render native Android UI elements at runtime; Sqlite3 to store an attribute-key-value datastore

protocols.protocol_text: Provision of code and software metadata tables with version numbers, repository links, licenses, and dependencies
Tracking of deployment counts and user statistics through FAIMS-led development activities
trigger_text: Considering only FAIMS-led development, approximately 300 users have logged over 20,000 h
FAIMS Mobile has been customised at least 40 times (by our team or independently)
protocols.inference_reasoning: Paper presents precise user and deployment statistics but does not describe how these metrics were collected, tracked, or verified. The tracking mechanism is implied but undocumented.

protocols.protocol_text: Reference to published case studies for detailed deployment evidence
protocols.verbatim_quote: Three deployment case studies have been published in Sobotkova et al., 2016

protocols.protocol_text: Feature-by-feature comparison narrative between FAIMS and ODK
trigger_text: It also includes features not found in ODK: more nuanced relationships between entities, bi-directional synchronisation
ODK also offers simpler but more restrictive customisation
protocols.inference_reasoning: Paper describes FAIMS features relative to ODK but doesn't document how features were selected for comparison or how equivalence was assessed.

protocols.protocol_text: Bulleted list format for software functionality documentation
protocols.verbatim_quote: These features include: Deep customisation of data schema, user interface, and automation

protocols.protocol_text: Screenshot figures illustrating software interface and functionality
protocols.verbatim_quote: FAIMS offers a variety of ways to record data (Fig. 1), all of which can be arranged hierarchically

protocols.protocol_text: Provision of multiple URLs for documentation, code, and executables
Perma.cc archival links provided alongside primary URLs for long-term accessibility

machine_actionability.rationale: Multiple GitHub repositories with clear version information (2.5/2.5.20), installation scripts, and documented dependencies. Permanent archive links via perma.cc provided.
Software publication - no research data to share. Deployment statistics mentioned but not published as dataset.

preregistration.notes: Software development paper - preregistration not applicable to this study type

findable.rationale: DOI assigned, multiple repository URLs, version numbers clearly stated, metadata table included

accessible.rationale: GPLv3 open source, multiple distribution channels (GitHub, Google Play, direct download), permanent archival links

interoperable.rationale: Standard formats (XML, JSON, SQLite), export capabilities documented, but proprietary Nutiteq component noted

reusable.rationale: Comprehensive documentation, module library for reuse, clear licensing, but requires Nutiteq license for non-watermarked GIS

funding.funder: National eResearch Collaboration Tools and Resources (NeCTAR)
New South Wales Government Research Attraction and Acceleration Program

known_uncertainties: Deployment tracking methodology not documented - unclear how 40 customisations and 300 users were counted
Case study findings referenced but details in external publication (Sobotkova et al. 2016)
User-reported outcomes lack methodological detail on how feedback was collected
Some features listed without usage evidence (e.g., Robotium testing support)
extraction_notes.extraction_approach: This is a methodological/software paper. Extracted software capabilities as evidence, software value propositions as claims, and implicit assumptions about technology adoption and generalisability. RDMAP focuses on documentation and impact assessment approaches rather than empirical research methodology.
